title: 114_hr6129
content:
The Act is titled the "Frank Moore Wild Steelhead Special Management Area Designation Act." Frank Moore, a World War II veteran and owner of the Steamboat Inn in Oregon, has dedicated his life to family, friends, his country, and fly fishing. He was awarded the Chevalier of the French Legion of Honor for his bravery during the D-Day Allied invasion. Moore and his wife shared their love of fishing and the outdoors with visitors from around the world at their inn along the North Umpqua River. Frank Moore, a WWII veteran and owner of the Steamboat Inn in Oregon, has dedicated his life to fishing and conservation efforts. He has received multiple awards for his work, including being inducted into the Fresh Water Fishing Hall of Fame. Approximately 99,653 acres of Forest Service land in Oregon are proposed to be named after him as the "Frank Moore Wild Steelhead Special Management Area." SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

Map: "Frank Moore Wild Steelhead Special Management Area Designation Act" map dated June 23, 2016.
Secretary: Secretary of Agriculture, through Chief of the Forest Service.
Special management area: Frank Moore Wild Steelhead Special Management Area designated by section 4(a).
State: State of Oregon.

SEC. 4. FRANK MOORE WILD STEELHEAD SPECIAL MANAGEMENT AREA, OREGON. The approximately 99,653 acres of Forest Service land in Oregon is designated as the "Frank Moore Wild Steelhead Special Management Area". The Secretary will prepare a map and legal description of the area, which will be available for public inspection. The Special Management Area in Oregon, known as the "Frank Moore Wild Steelhead Special Management Area," will be administered by the Secretary in accordance with laws applicable to the National Forest System. The area aims to conserve natural values, enhance salmonid habitat, maintain watershed as a refuge for wild salmonids, and preserve recreation opportunities. The Special Management Area in Oregon, named the "Frank Moore Wild Steelhead Special Management Area," will be managed by the Secretary in line with National Forest System laws. The area aims to conserve natural values, enhance salmonid habitat, maintain watershed as a refuge for wild salmonids, and preserve recreation opportunities. This section clarifies that state jurisdiction over fish and wildlife is unaffected, no protective perimeter or buffer zone is created, travel management plans remain unchanged, wildfire management is allowed, and vegetation management is not prohibited. Vegetation management projects within the Special Management Area are allowed as long as they align with the area's purposes and the applicable forest plan. Tribal treaty rights are not affected, and the Federal land within the area is withdrawn from various forms of entry, disposal, and mineral leasing laws.
